text: Syria is really a keystone of the whole
Middle East you know I like to say that
Libya implodes each of implode bahrain
implodes Syria explodes by dint of
geography the kind of government you
have in Damascus really will affect
governance in the very heart of the
Levant in the Arab Muslim world if Syria
were to collapse into some kind of chaos
or into a democratic process that
brought a new regime the two most
impacted players of course would be
first Iran which uses Syria as its
bridgehead with both Hamas in Gaza
because Hamas is headquarters are in
Syria and Hezbollah in Lebanon which
depends on the Syrian lifeline for arms
and money so if Syria were to collapse
you see him and you saw an emergency of
a sunni-led regime they would also
weaken I think the government in Tehran
which is why there are many reports I
can't confirm them one way or another
that Tehran has been buttressing the
Assad regime with money maybe even some
military advisers if you actually saw
the emergence of a democratic Syria it
would be fantastic because you'd see the
emergence of a democratic Lebanon I mean
Lebanon is a democracy but a deeply
flawed one that has had to suffer the
interventions of Syria ever since the
mid-1970s so I think if you saw a Syrian
regime that was really ready to treat
Lebanon as an equal not a vassal it
would enormously benefit the progressive
forces in Lebanon it would enormously
disadvantage those forces there like
Hezbollah that would lose its main arms
back I don't think it would disappear
but it would probably shrink back to its
a it's more natural and normal size
Egypt is a keystone in one way to the
Arab world politically but a Syria is I
would say geopolitically and that's why
what happens there really matters
